image.altText: A man with his head bandaged and in a wheelchair being whisked away and surrounded by people

props.synopsis: Adelaide man Keith Davis and his seriously injured wife are visited by the head of Singapore Airlines in a Bangkok hospital, as they seek a medical evacuation to Australia.

title.children: Singapore Airlines apologises to Australians seeking medical evacuation

image.altText: A court sketch depicts Donald Trump yawning. He wears a suit and blue ties.

props.synopsis: The rather shabby appearance of the criminal courthouse in lower Manhattan belies the history being made within its walls, as a jury prepares to deliberate over Donald Trump.

title.children: As we crammed into court, one big question remained. But after an abrupt answer, we hit the cliffhanger

image.altText: A view of the Seoul skyline with mountains in the background

props.synopsis: Seoul is one of the most expensive cities in the world, yet some students are only paying $11 a month in rent. Here's how they're doing it.

title.children: South Korea is offering small apartments for $11 a month. Why isn't Australia doing the same?

image.altText: Blue powerballs.

props.synopsis: A lucky ticket-holder has won the entire $150 million Powerball jackpot, becoming Australia's biggest individual lottery winner.

title.children: Australia's biggest lottery winner urged to claim $150 million prize

image.altText: Stack of several thousand dollars of Australian $50 notes

props.synopsis: Winning the lottery could be life-changing if you spend the money right. We spoke to four personal finance experts for their hypothetical tips if you were to receive a windfall.

title.children: What should you do if you've won the lotto or inherited millions? We asked four finance experts

image.altText: Boy wearing glasses with phone light reflecting on his lenses

props.synopsis: With a perfect biological and psychological storm stealing the slumber of teenagers, experts are calling for sleep to become a mainstay of their mental health treatment.

title.children: Teen circadian rhythms are different to the rest of us and could be key to improving their sleep and wellbeing

image.altText: Tina Turner belting into a microphone. She has short, curly blond hair and red lipstick. She's wearing a black lace chemise.

props.synopsis: A study by universities in SA and WA has sought to shed light on the origin of the popular Australian dance routine to American singer Tina Turner's 1973 song Nutbush City Limits, and has determined it was invented by the NSW education department.

title.children: The Nutbush dance is an Australian icon — but it owes its origins to a teachers' meeting

image.altText: The AFL logo on the side of a building, partially obscured by a tree branch.

props.synopsis: Lawyers representing former players in a racism class action against the AFL are looking to include all clubs in the competition.

title.children: Lawyers seek to pursue all AFL clubs in landmark racism class action

image.altText: Chelsea Hodges gives the thumbs up

props.synopsis: Chelsea Hodges swam the leg of her life to help Australia claim gold in the 4x100m medley relay in Tokyo, but the injury-hampered breaststroke swimmer opts out of Paris to prioritise her future health.

title.children: 'I have the hips of a 60-year-old': Why 22yo Olympic gold medalist has been forced to retire

image.altText: Scottie Scheffler waves

props.synopsis: The police officer who arrested world number one golfer Scottie Scheffler has been disciplined for failing to turn on his body-worn camera.

title.children: Police officer who arrested world number one golfer Scottie Scheffler disciplined as new video released

image.altText: Hannah Achelles in a bar

props.synopsis: Polycystic ovary syndrome (POCS) affects one in eight women and can have mild through to severe impacts on physical health, as well as emotional wellbeing including body image.

title.children: 'I feel like an ugly monster': The reality of living with PCOS

image.altText: A hand holds a COVID-19 rapid antigen test. The test shows two lines, indicating a positive result.

props.synopsis: With COVID cases rising across the country due to a new variant, FLiRT, we asked an infectious disease physician whether we should be worried and how to get over the virus quickly.

title.children: Is Australia facing another COVID-19 wave? Here's why case numbers are rising

image.altText: Taylor Swift performs at the Paris Le Defense Arena as a part of her Eras Tour concert in Paris, May 9, 2024

props.synopsis: Entertainment giant Ticketmaster is being sued by the US government over claims it is running an illegal live event "monopoly" which is hurting both artists and fans.

title.children: Illegal live event 'monopoly' being run by Ticketmaster, US government claims

image.altText: Paul Minuzzo wears a button-up shirt.

props.synopsis: A Queensland man was woken one night by a "ten out of ten pain". It was a fungal infection in his bone that led to his top jaw being surgically removed, and now he thinks it's coming back.

title.children: A fungal spore found 'everywhere in the environment' led to Paul Minuzzo losing his top jaw

image.altText: People sitting on a boat look out at a mountain and some rocks protruding from the ocean.

props.synopsis: Expeditioners at Australia's research station on Macquarie Island sometimes have to stay in mouldy, asbestos-riddled accommodation blocks. To improve conditions and enhance scientific capabilities, a major upgrade costing hundreds of millions of dollars is underway.

title.children: Expeditioners love visiting 'beautiful' Macquarie Island, except for the mouldy, asbestos-riddled accommodation

image.altText: A woman looks on with her hands behind her head.

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly News Quiz: A cat with a doctorate, Sam Kerr and counting koalas

image.altText: Black and white photo fo Kings of Leon holding balloons.

props.synopsis: After decades of putting immense pressure on themselves, Kings Of Leon just wanted to have a good time when making their new album.

title.children: After decades of pressure, Kings Of Leon are learning how to have fun again

image.altText: A young woman lies in bed looking worried.

props.synopsis: Kat Sadler was worried people wouldn't understand her comedy series Such Brave Girls — the characters are flawed, and the comedy is pitch black and sometimes shocking. But it's been a smash hit, winning awards and being renewed for a second season.

title.children: Kat Sadler's struggles landed her in a psych ward. Then she turned them into a hit TV comedy

image.altText: The sun rises over a blue planet

props.synopsis: In 2016, astronomers published a study suggesting a ninth planet could be hiding on the edge of our Solar System. Eight years later, they're still looking for it. So what will it take to find it?

title.children: 'There's something going on': Why this astronomer is convinced Planet Nine exists

image.altText: A crowd pulses through the city

props.synopsis: The recent debate highlights a deeper issue in how we treat those who come to Australia seeking better opportunities. It's time to reconsider how we view migrants and listen to their voices during times of public and political outcry.

title.children: Is blaming migrants for the housing crisis anything more than a political stunt ahead of next year's election?

image.altText: A photo showing an old man wearing a white polo shirt with trees in the background

props.synopsis: Almost two years after they won a $50 million settlement from the federal government, descendants of NT Stolen Generations are yet to receive any compensation, and say the wait is adding to their trauma.

title.children: Delays to $50m Stolen Generations settlement payment adding to trauma, descendants say

image.altText: A close-up of a doctor's hand pressing an ultrasound tool on a pregnant woman's belly

props.synopsis: Clinicians say regular, consistent screening of pregnant women for depression and childhood trauma could help detect those who are victims of intimate partner violence.

title.children: Doctors call for more screening of domestic violence during pregnancy check-ups

image.altText: A man uses a newspaper as others use umbrellas to protect themselves from the heat.

props.synopsis: As India's election campaign approaches the finish line, voters allege they have been beaten up by police at polling stations, while candidates say they have been encouraged to withdraw from the race.

title.children: A worker from Narendra Modi's party was filmed plotting to bribe police. Then he was arrested

image.altText: The exterior of the Nvidia HQ in Santa Clara.

props.synopsis: The major US share indices have slipped as fears of higher interest rates for longer outweighed continued optimism in the tech sector over AI, which saw Nvidia's share price jump by more than 9 per cent. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US shares slide on rate fears despite Nvidia's $US218b rally, with ASX set to follow lower

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Futures close to the mark as ASX 200 opens 1 per cent lower
Origin Energy boss says Eraring closure delay secures renewable energy transition
Good news is bad news in the US as rate fears rise again

image.altText: woman sitting in her van with possessions in the back

props.synopsis: Homeless since returning to Australia seven months ago, Dr Selene Routley is a physicist and space scientist who makes a small income writing articles for science magazines. She currently sleeps in a van packed to the brim with her possessions.

title.children: Homeless physicist 'sick of smelling of my own BO' living in a van in a region with impossible rent

image.altText: Mother wearing black vest smiles at camera

props.synopsis: There are currently 4,500 support classes for students with moderate to high needs across NSW, but demand continues to skyrocket as parents prepare for their school leavers for year 7.

title.children: With high school around the corner, 12yo Will is still waiting for a vital support class placement

image.altText: A graphic using shots of Ros Bates and Shannon Fentiman.

props.synopsis: A senior Queensland Opposition MP has been referred to a powerful parliamentary ethics committee after refusing to withdraw an accusation a minister had incited violence against her.

title.children: 'Cross your legs': Queensland MP provides context as she's referred to ethics committee over accusation

image.altText: a flowering canola crop. the sky has some clouds

props.synopsis: West Australian canola growers have been refunded more than $600,000 from a seed company after successfully arguing their consumer rights had been breached by widespread pre-harvest crop deaths.

title.children: Farmers win $600k payout under Australian consumer law after canola seeds died before harvest

image.altText: a red ferrari racecar is waved through a checkpoint

props.synopsis: Dreamt up from a Hollywood fantasy, the Cannonball Run was set to put the Northern Territory on the global stage. But the event seemed destined for tragedy before it began.

title.children: 30 years on from the worst crash in Australian motorsport history

image.altText: A man sitting on the ground with handcuffs on, with his back to the camera, surrounded by other men.

props.synopsis: The first reported comments from the man accused of attempting to murder the Slovakian prime minister shed some light on a potential motive.

title.children: Man suspected of shooting Slovak PM wanted to hurt him, not kill him, court documents reveal

image.altText: A curtain of blue lights hang in a circle creating a curtain of colour in a sydney park at night.

document.synopsis: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.

synopsisAlt.lg: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.
synopsisAlt.sm: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.

children.content: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.

teaserText.plain: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.

document.title: Vivid festival will return to Sydney on May 24

titleAlt.lg: Vivid festival will return to Sydney on May 24
titleAlt.md: Vivid festival will return to Sydney on May 24
titleAlt.sm: Vivid festival will return to Sydney on May 24

document.caption: The Vivid light festival will run from May 24 to June 15 2024.

props.synopsis: Sydney will soon be bathed in light as the Vivid festival kicks off. This year, there will be rave trains doing laps of the city and undergrounds tunnels dancing with pyrotechnics to explore, as well as a world of colour projected on to buildings across the city.

title.children: Vivid Sydney is back and this year, the light festival is hitting the train tracks
